Ian, 
 
 I am curious as to why you specifically exclude self defense as a valid reason for owning a gun. Data from the FBI shows that victims who resist an aggressor by use of a gun are less likely to be injured than when the use other weapons for defense. I would think that this alone would validate the ownership of a gun for defensive use. On a related note, as was recently confirmed by the SCOTUS, owning a firearm is an individual right. I am not aware of any other right that you are required to to demonstrate a reason prior to exercising.
 
 I don't think you will find too many people that don't think that some form of regulation is needed with regard to guns, the question remains to be what form and how much regulation.
 
 As for resisting our government...Even our government recognizes the damage that a small group can inflict on a military unit. This is why we train soldiers in guerrilla warfare. We just don't call it that in the military. It is usually referred to as special forces, or in the Navy, as Unconventional Warfare Specialists. A small group of accomplished marksman, with a knowledge of military troop movements and structure can be truly devastating to a military unit. Our country has many veterans with just such knowledge, and a even more gun owners that exceed the average soldier in capabilities with a firearm.
 
 There are also a certain number of men and women within the military that would refuse to act on the part of our government in such a case. Everyone in the military understands that they have a duty to their fellow Americans and that any order that conflicts with the laws of the land, is an illegal order. There are still those that would indeed rise against their fellow countrymen, but I think you would find that this action would be less than seamlessly coordinated. This confusion would add to the difficulty of bringing action against the people through military force, but it would not likely be enough to make it impossible.
 
 While an armed populace does not stand a good chance of being victorious in a protracted, all out war with our own government, history has shown that many times in a conflict, the decimation of the enemy is not required to be victorious. Simply having and using the means to resist can be a powerful deterrent and weapon.
